academic.def: Not self-indulgent, especially when eating and drinking.
Something out of its proper time, belonging to an earlier period.
Demonstrating aggression and willingness to fight.
Having knowledge or being aware of something.
A division between two things represented as being opposed.
The theory of knowledge, especially with regard to its methods.
Very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail.
Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group.
Existing in something as a permanent, essential attribute.
Place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.
Using very few words.
Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
In the form of a cloud or haze; hazy or vague.
To render obscure, unclear, or unintelligible.
A typical example or pattern of something; a model.
In a state or period of inactivity or dormancy.
Obstinately uncooperative toward authority or discipline.
Most noticeable or important.
Able to be maintained or defended against attack or objection.
Present, appearing, or found everywhere.
Regard with great respect; revere.
Beaten into shape by hammering (of metals); highly finished.
Dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries.
Produce or provide; give way to arguments or demands.
A person who is fanatical and uncompromising in pursuit of ideals.
Make something bad or unsatisfactory better.
Well meaning and kindly.
The quality of being open and honest in expression; frankness.
Showing humble submission and respect.
Cheerful and full of energy.
Treating serious issues with inappropriate humor.
Uncalled for; lacking good reason; unwarranted.
Arrogantly superior and disdainful.
Too great to be expressed or described in words.
Special words used by a profession that are difficult for others to understand.
Praise and honor received for an achievement.
Affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic.
Generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival.
Excessive interest in or admiration of oneself.
Having unlimited power; able to do anything.
Spreading widely throughout an area or a group of people.
Complaining in a petulant or whining manner.
Not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily.
A person who acts obsequiously toward someone important.
Reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little.
Take a position of power or importance illegally or by force.
Alternate or waver between different opinions or actions.
Feeling or showing caution about possible dangers or problems.
Relating to hospitality between host and guest.
Join or combine two things, often in a restrictive way.
The time at which something is most powerful or successful.
Bitterness or ill feeling.
So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring.
Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior.
Intended to teach, particularly in having moral instruction.
The skill of clear and expressive speech.
Sparing or economical with regard to money or food.
Fond of company; sociable.
The practice of claiming to have moral standards to which one does not conform.
Acting or done quickly and without thought or care.
Having, showing, or done with good judgment or sense.
Blood relationship; a sharing of characteristics or origins.
Tending to talk a great deal; talkative.
A general feeling of discomfort, illness, or uneasiness.
Wicked or criminal.
Exclude someone from a society or group.
Eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight.
A state of perplexity or uncertainty over what to do.
Bitterness or resentfulness, especially when long-standing.
Not being what it purports to be; false or fake.
Very weak or slight.
Not conspicuous or attracting attention.
Bitter and abusive.
Having or showing a feeling of vague or regretful longing.

A feeling of intense longing for something.
A soft gentle breeze.
Brisk and cheerful readiness.
Noisy, energetic, and cheerful; rowdy.
The use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose.
A ruler or other person who holds absolute power.
Mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper.
Happening by accident or chance rather than design.
Sly or cunning intelligence.
Excessive pride or self-confidence.
A mode of behavior or way of thought peculiar to an individual.
Cheerful and friendly.
The sound of a bell, especially when rung solemnly for a death or funeral.
Displaying or having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort.
A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
Feeling or appearing casually calm and relaxed.
Obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree.
A solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases.
Exceedingly idealistic; unrealistic and impractical.
Think deeply about something.
Optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently bad or difficult situation.
The quality or state of being calm.
Offense or annoyance.
Vehement or clamorous.
Attractive or appealing in appearance or character.
Deviating from what is standard, normal, or expected.
Hostile and aggressive.
An event causing great and often sudden damage or distress.

Make a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling worse.
Start to lose strength or momentum.

Unchanging over time or unable to be changed.
Tired, bored, or lacking enthusiasm.

Producing a great deal of profit.
Of only moderate quality; not very good.
A connection or series of connections linking two or more things.
Remove a need or difficulty.
Make a disease or its symptoms less severe without removing the cause.
Summarize and state again the main points of.

Divide into two branches or forks.
Confirm or give support to (a statement, theory, or finding).
Essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison.
Open to more than one interpretation; ambiguous.
Having or displaying a passionate intensity.
Relating to knowledge, especially esoteric mystical knowledge.
Enabling a person to discover or learn something for themselves.

Able to be hammered or pressed permanently out of shape.
Just coming into existence and beginning to display potential.

Translucently clear.

Modeled on or aiming for a state in which everything is perfect.
Experienced in the imagination through the actions of another.
Shake with a quivering motion; be undecided between two opinions.
An affection for unknown objects or people.
A person who performs great and loyal service.
Great enthusiasm and energy.
A person who believes that nothing is known or can be known of the existence or nature of God.
Showing a disinterested and selfless concern for the well-being of others.
The state of having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something.
A person or thing that is the direct opposite of someone or something else.
Showing great care and perseverance.
Severe or strict in manner, attitude, or appearance.
The right or condition of self-government.
Concise and exact use of words in writing or speech.
A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds.
A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change.
Wary and unwilling to take risks.
Come together to form one mass or whole.
A feeling of guilt or moral scruple that prevents or follows the doing of something bad.
The junction of two rivers, especially of equal width.
Causing or likely to cause an argument; controversial.
Flash or sparkle.
A tendency to be too ready to believe that something is real or true.
Hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed.
Behavior in keeping with good taste and propriety.
A political leader who seeks support by appealing to the desires and prejudices of ordinary people rather than by using rational argument.
Lacking a plan, purpose, or enthusiasm.
A forceful and bitter verbal attack against someone or something.
Modest or shy because of a lack of self-confidence.
Regard or represent as being of little worth.
Inclined to lay down principles as incontrovertibly true.
Deceitfulness; double-dealing.
Deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.
Successful in producing a desired or intended result; effective.
Outstandingly bad; shocking.

Based on, concerned with, or verifiable by observation or experience rather than theory or pure logic.

Lasting for a very short time.
Mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation.
Having or showing great knowledge or learning.
Intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest.

Treating serious issues with inappropriate humor.
Based on a mistaken belief.

Happening by accident or chance rather than design.

Believing in or practicing religious heresy.

Unchanging over time or unable to be changed.

Not telling the truth; lying.
Subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind.

Speak or act in an evasive way.
In its original condition; unspoiled.

literary.def: Denoting a highly ornamented style of language.
Relating to the pleasant aspects of the countryside.
Kept secret or done secretively, especially if illicit.
A state of disuse.
Lasting for a very short time.
Intense happiness; the ability to find appropriate expression.
Referring to something very light, thin, and delicate.
Denoting a period of time in the past that was idyllically happy.
Emitting light as a result of being heated; passionate.
Feeling or expressing great happiness and triumph.
Full of or shedding light; bright or shining.
A sound that is sweet or musical; pleasant to hear.
Showing varying colors as an opal does.
Extreme poverty; destitution.
Attractive and impressive through being richly colorful.
Everlasting; eternal.
Objects thought to have magic powers or bring good luck.
A brilliant deep blue color.
A trace of something that is disappearing or no longer exists.
